title: Cloudtrail Service is disabled
summary: CloudTrail logging is not enabled for this region. It should be enabled.

title: Global Cloudtrail is not enabled
summary: Global CloudTrail logging is not enabled. It should be enabled.

title: EC2 instance - Alert to Kill
summary: EC2 - Alert to Kill - Checks for instances with improper or no tags then kills any matching instances within the first 5 minutes.

title: EC2 Inventory results
summary: EC2 Inventory results.

title: Security Group contains IP address
summary: Security Group contains IP address

title: Security group contains a port range
summary: Security group contains a port range rather than specifying individual ports.

title: TCP port is open
summary: Important TCP port is open, potentially to the world.

title: Security group allows unrestricted traffic
summary: All IP addresses are allowed to access resources in the affected security group.

title: ELB is using most recent Amazon SSL policy
summary: Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) SSL policy is current (most recent Amazon predefined SSL policy).

title: Classic ELB Inventory results
summary: Classic Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) Inventory results.

title: ELB is using old SSL policy
summary: Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) SSL policy is not the latest Amazon predefined SSL policy or is a custom ELB SSL policy.

title: Active user Access Key not rotated
summary: User has active keys that have not been rotated in the last 90 days.

title: Passwords not set to expire
summary: The current password policy doesn't require users to regularly change their passwords. User passwords are set to never expire.

title: Inactive user Access Key not rotated
summary: User has inactive keys that have not been rotated in the last 90 days.

title: Password policy doesn't exist
summary: There currently isn't a password policy to require a certain password length, password expiration, prevent password reuse, and other parameters.

title: Account has multiple active access keys
summary: The affected account has multiple active AWS access keys.

title: Multi-Factor Authentication not enabled
summary: Affected user does not have Multi-Factor Authentication enabled on their account

title: Users can reuse old passwords
summary: The current password policy doesn't prevent users from reusing their old passwords.

title: Root user has active Access Key
summary: Root user has an Access Key that is active

title: Root user has active password
summary: Root user has been logging in with a password.

title: Multi-Factor Authentication not enabled for root account
summary: Root user does not have Multi-Factor Authentication enabled on their cloud account

title: Unused or empty IAM group
summary: There is an IAM group defined without any users in it and therefore unused.

title: Account using inline policies
summary: User account is using custom inline policies versus using IAM group managed policies.

title: RDS is Publicly Accessible to the world
summary: The affected RDS database is Publicly Accessible to the world.

title: RDS not set to automatically upgrade
summary: RDS is not set to automatically upgrade minor versions on your database instance

title: RDS short backup retention period
summary: The affected RDS database has a short backup retention period (less than 30 days).

title: Redshift cluster data is not encrypted at rest
summary: Redshift cluster data in the affected cluster is not encrypted at rest.

title: Redshift connections not SSL
summary: Connections to Redshift aren't set to require the use of SSL encryption.

title: Redshift user activity logging disabled
summary: Redshift user activity logging is disabled.

title: Redshift automatic major version upgrades not enabled
summary: Redshift automatic major version upgrades not enabled.

title: Redshift cluster is publicly accessible
summary: The affected Redshift cluster is publicly accessible to the world.

title: Redshift default TCP port 5439 is open to the world
summary: Redshift default TCP port 5439 is open, potentially to the world.

title: All users can list the affected bucket
summary: Bucket has permissions (ACL) which let anyone list the bucket contents.

title: All users can write the bucket ACP / ACL
summary: Bucket has permissions (ACP / ACL) which let all users modify the permissions

title: All users can write to the affected bucket
summary: Bucket has permissions (ACL) which let all users write to the bucket.

title: All authenticated AWS users can read the affected bucket
summary: Bucket has permissions which let any AWS authenticated user list the bucket contents.

title: All authenticated AWS users can change bucket permissions
summary: Bucket has permissions which let any AWS authenticated user modify the permissions.

title: All authenticated AWS users can write to the affected bucket
summary: Bucket has permissions which lets any AWS users write to the bucket.

title: S3 bucket logging not enabled
summary: S3 bucket logging has not been enabled for the affected resource.

title: Bucket policy uses IP addresses to grant permission
summary: Bucket policy grants permissions to any user at an IP address or range to perform operations on objects in the affected bucket.

title: Bucket policy gives world Get, Put, List, and Delete permission
summary: Bucket policy allows the world to get, put, list, and delete the affected bucket.

title: Bucket policy gives world delete permission
summary: Bucket policy allows the world to delete the affected bucket.

title: Bucket policy gives world Get permission
summary: Bucket policy allows the world to get the contents of the affected bucket.

title: Bucket policy gives world List permission
summary: Bucket policy allows the world to list the contents of the affected bucket

title: Bucket policy gives world Put permission
summary: Bucket policy allows the world to put data into the affected bucket.

title: Scroll layout
summary: This page demonstrates how you the integration of a script called ScrollTo, which is used here to link definitions of a JSON code sample to a list of definitions for that particular term. The scenario here is that the JSON blocks are really long, with extensive nesting and subnesting, which makes it difficult for tables below the JSON to adequately explain the term in a usable way.
